title: Ticket #6031: Improve RANK documentation
description:
On 11/30/2016 2:00 PM, Aaron Moate wrote: > Below is HTCondor manual section 3.5.1.4 regarding RANK > expressions. I believe RANK only effects jobs that are > already running in comparison to jobs that are being > considered for matches (as opposed to two jobs that are > not yet running and being considered for matches)? > And that if preemption is disabled then RANK is meaningless? > If this is so, I would suggest making section 3.5.1.4 > more clear. Reading it gives me the impression that > RANK will effect matchmaking while the slot is idle > (which it may? This has always confused me). > > -Moate

Hi Moate,

Your belief is correct; startd RANK only effects jobs that are already running. People on htcondor-users often have the same confusion; in fact, I answered a question about this very topic just a few days ago --- see the below email thread. You do subscribe to htcondor-users, right? ;-) Kent, below may have text you can lift for improving the documentation in the section Moate referenced.

regards, Todd

-------- Forwarded Message -------- Subject: Re: Jobs taking a long time to match Date: Tue, 22 Nov 2016 13:28:38 -0600 From: Todd Tannenbaum <tannenba@cs.wisc.edu> To: Szabolcs Horvátth <szabolcs.horvatth@gmail.com>, htcondor-users@cs.wisc.edu

On 11/22/2016 1:00 PM, Szabolcs Horvátth wrote: > Hi, > > I'm trying to find the reason why some of our condor jobs can take a > really long time to get matched. The situation is the following: > > - There are submitted jobs that have high machine rank so they are > supposed to start as soon as slots are available. > - There are available slots that match the job requirements, condor_q > analyze confirms that, but other users' lower ranked jobs get matched to > these slots.

Setting the startd rank (i.e. RANK = .... in condor_config) does not control how fast slots get matched, nor does it prevent lower ranked jobs from getting matched to those slots.

What startd rank DOES do is tells the startd "if possible, preempt and replace the currently running job with a higher ranked idle job". Essentially, it is a way for the machine to rank how much it likes the job it is currently matched with, and tells the condor_negotiator to keep looking for a match it likes better than its current one.

So if a machine has an unclaimed slot, it will first be offered to the highest priority user (regardless of startd RANK). Once the slot is claimed by the highest priority user with a job that matches the slot, startd RANK kicks in and the condor_negotiator will continue to look to see if there are jobs from a different user that RANK higher - if so, the job from the highest priority user will be preempted and replaced with the job that ranks higher.

Note that startd RANK always implies preemption- if you don't want job to be preempted, startd rank does not help you.

If you want to control who gets "first shot" at a slot, you would normally adjust user priorities (aka condor_userprio -setfactor user@domain 1) or group quotas.

If you want to increase the frequency at which matchmaking occurs (it only happens every NEGOTIATOR_INTERVAL seconds, or when someone run condor_submit, condor_reschedule), decrease NEGOTIATOR_INTERVAL.

Hope the above helps, Todd
